Strong metal support interaction (SMSI) between precious metals and metal oxide support is an effective strategy to improve catalyst activity. However, the interfacial effects of SMSI on the catalyst surface are not clear. In this paper, Pt/MnO2 catalysts with different MnO2 crystal structures (β- and γ-) are used as research objects, and operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS is used as characterization technique. Pt/β-MnO2 exhibited the highest CO oxidation activity (200 °C) and CO2 selectivity (100 °C) due to its excellent redox properties. Among them, β-MnO2 surface Pt mainly exists in the form of elemental Pt, while γ-MnO2 surface Pt mainly exists in the form of PtO2. Different forms of Pt have positive and negative effects on different MnO2 crystals. DFT results show that Pt/β-MnO2 has strong adsorption capacity for CO. Operando DRIFTS results indicate that Pt/β-MnO2 surface PtO first reacts with CO to produce PtOv (Ov represent oxygen vacancy) at low temperature. As the temperature rises, MnO and Pt-O-Mn also participate in CO reaction, forming MnOv, Pt-Ov-Mn and gas-phase CO2. It is worth noting that the formation of Pt-Ov-Mn plays an important role in the activation of O2. The surface carbonate of the catalyst inhibited the activation of Pt-Ov-Mn. More PtO sites are conducive to the production of monodentate carbonate and the easier decomposition at low temperature, which is the decisive step of CO oxidation. These findings provide strong support for understanding the effect of SMSI effect on the intrinsic configuration of catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Pt/MnO2 catalysts SMSI operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS Carbonate species Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon monoxide comes mainly from the incomplete combustion of carbon-containing fuels. In addition, the exhaust gases of internal combustion engines and the combustion of fossil fuels in boilers are also major sources of CO in the atmosphere. Excessive CO emissions can cause harm to human health, causing the loss of oxygen-carrying capacity of hemoglobin in human blood, causing suffocation and even death [1–3]. In order to reduce CO emission, catalytic oxidation is one of the more effective means at this stage [4,5]. Among them, catalysts commonly used in catalytic oxidation are mainly divided into precious metal catalysts and transition metal catalysts [6,7]. Noble metal catalysts have excellent catalytic activity and selectivity. It can efficiently promote chemical reactions and has good stability. However, its high cost and easy aggregation or poisoning have greatly limited its application [8,9]. Transition metal catalysts have low cost and abundant resources. Although it shows good catalytic activity in some specific reactions, it also has some obvious disadvantages [10]. For example, pure transition metal catalysts have poor catalytic activity and selectivity. It is also susceptible to environmental factors such as oxidation, agglomeration/dissolution. In order to further improve the CO removal efficiency, it can be considered to use the transition metal as the carrier and the precious metal catalyst as the active center to increase the surface active site and oxygen species of the catalyst [11,12]. Strong metal-supported interactions (SMSI) between precious metals and transition metal oxides can significantly improve the catalytic performance and stability of catalysts [13,14]. In 1978s, Tauster et al. were the first to reveal the existence of the SMSI effect. They found that the adsorption capacity of platinum group metals on titanium dioxide to small molecules such as CO or H2 was significantly reduced. Based on the experimental results, Tauster et al. proposed the theory of strong interaction between metal and support (SMSI concept) [15]. Recently, the SMSI effect has played a key role in catalytic oxidation, reforming reaction, and water-gas shift, which has promoted the resurgence of SMSI research in the field of heterogeneous catalysis [16,17]. SMSI catalyst system is mainly reflected in the reduction of chemical adsorption capacity of small molecules after metal loading, and promote the migration of the carrier to the supported metal, the transfer of electrons between the metal and the carrier, and the oxidation reduction of the catalyst. As a noble metal, Pt has excellent catalytic activity and stability, and can efficiently promote the reaction. As a carrier, MnO2 with different crystal structures (α-, β-, γ-, ε-, and λ-) has good redox ability and electron transport characteristics, which can have a strong interaction with Pt and optimize the catalytic performance [18]. The combination of Pt and MnO2 can give full play to their respective advantages, optimize the performance of the catalyst, and improve the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. Mo et al. [18] prepared a variety of Pt/MnO2 catalysts to explore the oxidation characteristics of toluene. The results showed that the interaction between Pt and MnO2 improved the low-temperature reducibility of the catalyst and optimized the surface chemical state. Scarllett et al. [19] prepared the role of Pt/MnO2-Ir electrocatalyst in oxygen reduction reaction. The results showed that the SMSI effect of MnO2 and Pt would enhance the (oxygen reduction reaction) ORR process. Although the SMSI effect formed by the combination of Pt and MnO2 greatly improves the catalytic activity. However, it is not clear which reactive oxygen species (intermediates) and metal transition states play a key role in the surface interface of SMSI effects. Therefore, it is urgent to find a reliable characterization method to study the reaction mechanism at the interface of the catalyst surface, so as to lay a theoretical foundation for the development of high-performance catalysts. Operando DRIFTS spectroscopy is one of the effective methods to investigate surface mechanism. The technology enables on-site analysis of the reaction process in real time and provides information about the material surface, volume, chemical reaction and interface adsorption [20,21]. Alkhoori et al. [22] investigated the effect of Ni/CeO2/Al2O3 catalyst system on methane oxidation. Operando DRIFTS analysis showed that CO species and bicarbonate adsorbed on Ni surface were the key active reaction intermediates in the process of methane oxidation, which played an important role in the catalytic effect. Platero et al. [23] prepared cobalt-supported TiO2 catalysts. Operando CO-DRIFT results showed that the catalyst was strongly affected by negative SMSI during reduction at higher temperatures. Although the SMSI effect has been reported in a large number of literatures, there are few studies on surface different oxygen species and intermediates. The oxygen species present on the surface of catalysts are essential for catalytic reactions and encompass several primary types, such as adsorbed oxygen (Oads), surface active oxygen (M2 +-O2 2−, M+-O2 −, and M=O etc), and lattice oxygen (Olatt) [24]. Surface reactive oxygen species react with CO molecules as the active site. In addition, the type and distribution of reactive oxygen species also affect the CO oxidation process [25]. By controlling the generation and distribution of reactive oxygen species on the catalyst, the activity and stability of the catalyst can be improved [26]. Xu et al. [27] used operando DRIFTS technology to investigate α-MnO2 catalysts with different morphologies. The results showed that the Mn-based catalyst containing more T-type oxygen (MnO) on the surface is beneficial to the oxidation of CO at lower temperature. Shi et al. [28] investigated the catalytic oxidation of HCHO and C6H6 with four different crystalline phase MnO2 catalysts. The results showed that different oxygen species had different reaction characteristics to different VOCs. In this paper, MnO2 catalysts with different crystal structures (β- and γ-) modified by Pt are used as the research object. The positive and negative effects of SMSI in CO oxidation are systematically investigated by various characterization techniques and DFT calculations. Operando DRIFTS spectroscopy to explore the active sites on the surface of the catalyst and the role of surface intermediates during CO reactions. The mechanism of related CO oxidation under SMSI effect is also revealed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation β- and γ-MnO2 catalysts are prepared by hydrothermal method. In addition, Pt/β- and γ-MnO2 are prepared by loading method. Detailed preparation steps for each MnO2 catalyst can be found in the Supplementary information. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), N2 physical adsorption and desorption (N2-sorption), scanning electron microscope (SEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM), and Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) are used to characterize the properties of the prepared catalysts. The specific methods are described in the Supplementary information. 2.3 Catalyst activity evaluation A quantity of 200 mg (40–60 mesh) MnO2 catalyst powder is loaded into a quartz tube reactor. The temperature inside the reactor is then increased to 350 °C to activate the catalyst for 1 h using an O2/Ar gas mixture (flow rate of 80 mL min–1). Once the temperature is brought back down to room temperature, a gas mixture (1 vol% CO/Ar and 20 % O2/Ar, total flow rate 102.5 mL min–1) is introduced. Subsequently, the temperature is raised from room temperature to 250 °C to evaluate the impact of the catalyst on CO oxidation. Throughout the procedure, the hourly space velocity (GHSV) of the gas is maintained at 30,000 mL·g−1·h−1. Each temperature point is tested for 1 h, and the conversion rate of CO (x) is determined using Eq. (1): (1) x = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 [CO]in and [CO]out indicate the levels of CO in the gases entering and exiting the reactor, respectively. In the Supplementary information, a detailed description of the specific calculation process for determining the activation energy (Ea, kJ mol–1) of CO oxidation on different catalysts has been provided. 2.4 Operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS The reaction pathway of CO on the catalyst as well as the formation of gas-phase products are thoroughly examined using CO as probe molecules via operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS. Furthermore, Supplementary information provides detailed steps and descriptions of operando CO2-TPR-DRIFTS-MS. Operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS system is comprised of several components, such as an infrared spectrometer (Nicolet 50, Thermo Scientific, USA), an MCT-A detector, and a temperature controller (HVC-DRP-5, Harrick, USA). For stability and precision during experiments, the gas flow rate is precisely regulated using a mass flow meter (MFC, D07, Seven Star Huachuang, China), as illustrated in Fig. S1. The in-situ cell contains 100 mg of catalysts with the total intake of reaction gas set at 20 mL min–1. To maintain catalyst activity, the catalyst in the reaction cell undergoes pretreatment at 300 °C in a 20 % O2/Ar atmosphere for 30 min. Following this, the catalyst is cooled to room temperature and allowed to stabilize for 30 min to gather the background spectrum of DRIFTS. Each catalyst is adsorbed at 25 °C using 1 % CO/Ar gas (without O2) or 1 % CO/Ar and 20 % O2 atmosphere (with O2) for 20 min. The temperature is then gradually ramped up from 25 °C to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Throughout the heating process, the infrared spectrometer conducts scans at a frequency of 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1 to accurately capture the subtle changes in the CO reaction path on the catalyst surface. Simultaneously, mass spectrometry (MS) (LC-D200M, Ametek, USA) is utilized to analyze the gas products in the reaction cell. Particular focus is placed on acquiring MS signals, including CO (m/z = 28), CO2 (m/z = 44), and O2 (m/z = 32). In order to gain understanding of the generation of gas-phase products during the reaction. 2.5 DFT calculation Supplementary information provides detailed steps and descriptions of DFT calculation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and surface analysis The morphology, microstructure and surface element distribution of different Pt/MnO2 catalysts are investigated by SEM, TEM and Mapping. The experiment results are shown in Fig. 1. According to the SEM results in Fig. 1(a) and (g), Pt/(β- and γ-)MnO2 catalysts have different morphological characteristics. Pt/β-MnO2 appears as nanoneedles with lengths and thicknesses of about 1.0 μm and 32 nm, respectively. Pt/γ-MnO2 appears as a nanosheet forming a petal shape with a thickness of about 21 nm. Meanwhiles, TEM images ( Fig. 2(b, c) and 2 (h, i)) show that the prepared Pt NPs in a different form are uniformly dispersed on the surface of β-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 catalysts. Pt NPs mainly exist in the form of nano-particulate matter (elemental matter) in β-MnO2. Its diameter and lattice fringe are 1.461 nm and 0.230 nm, respectively. The lattice fringe of 0.230 nm corresponds to the (110) crystal plane of Pt, which is consistent with the literature [18]. It is worth noting that the presence of Pt particles is not found on the γ-MnO2 surface. However, in addition to the γ-MnO2 (131) crystal plane, the existence of crystal plane fringe of 0.319 nm is found. According to the literature, it can be found that it corresponds to PtO2(110) crystal plane [16]. This suggests the predominant presence of Pt compounds on the surface of γ-MnO2. It is noteworthy that the surface of Pt/β-MnO2 and Pt/γ-MnO2 catalysts displayed more indistinct lattice features (indicated by dotted red lines). According to the literature, the generation of fuzzy lattice fringes is related to surface defects [16]. Above experimental findings demonstrate that a significant quantity of Pt nanoparticles is effectively bonded to the surface of MnO2 carriers with distinct crystal forms, confirming the presence of solid-solid interface interaction (SMSI) on the catalyst's surface. ICP and Mapping analysis are performed to further confirm the presence of Pt NPs in the samples ( Table 1 and Fig. 1(d-f) and (j-l)). The mapping results unequivocally indicate that the synthesized Pt/(β- and γ-)MnO2 catalysts consist of Mn, O, and Pt elements, providing full confirmation that Pt NPs have indeed been effectively loaded onto distinct MnO2 carriers. In addition, the ICP analysis results for both Pt/MnO2 samples are close to 1 wt%, which indicates that the Pt loading on the surface of these two catalysts is essentially the same. 3.2 Catalytic activity analysis Fig. 2 displays the assessment of the catalytic performance of various MnO2 catalysts for CO oxidation. The addition of Pt to MnO2 with different crystal structures results in varying catalytic activity compared to the pure MnO2 catalysts of the corresponding crystal structures (Fig. 2(a, b)). The ranking of catalytic activity at T 90 is Pt/β-MnO2 (150 °C) > γ-MnO2 (175 °C) > β-MnO2 (210 °C) > Pt/γ-MnO2 (300°C). By comparing the T 90 value (that is the temperature required for 90 % of CO to be converted to CO2), it's evident that the Pt/β-MnO2 catalysts require a significantly lower conversion temperature than pure β-MnO2 catalysts. Meanwhiles, Pt/β-MnO2 catalysts have best CO2 selectivity (98 %) at T 90 . These may be due to the fact that Pt/β-MnO2 has more reaction sites on the vector surface and the interaction between Pt NPs and MnO2 vector is more significant. However, the CO oxidation activity of Pt/γ-MnO2 is just the opposite. This observation may to be associated with the distinct crystal structure of the MnO2 catalysts or the manner in which Pt nanoparticles are present. The apparent activation energy (E a ) is calculated to assess the intrinsic activity of the catalyst (Fig. 2(c)). The E a values of different MnO2 catalysts are Pt/β-MnO2 (E a =10.6 ± 1.1 kJ mol–1) < γ-MnO2 (E a =27.5 ± 1.1 kJ mol–1) < β-MnO2 (E a =43.2 ± 1.2 kJ mol–1) < Pt/γ-MnO2 (E a =51.4 ± 1.2 kJ mol–1). Pt/β-MnO2 catalyst has the lowest E a value and the lowest activation temperature [29]. Meanwhiles, the turnover frequency (TOF) of different MnO2 catalysts is also evaluated (Fig. 2(d)). Pt/β-MnO2 has the best TOF (0.05 μmol min–1 m–2) at 50 ℃. As the temperature increases, the TOF value of different MnO2 catalysts also increase. The results are consistent with the activity test results. 3.3 Crystal structure analysis The results of structural characterization of different MnO2 catalysts by XRD are shown in Fig. 3(a). The XRD patterns of the two MnO2 catalysts with different morphologies are perfectly matched with the standard cards of β-MnO2 (JCPDS-24–0735) and γ-MnO2 (JCPDS-39–0375) [16]. It is noteworthy that the angle of β-MnO2 (110) and γ-MnO2 (131) crystal faces is shifted towards low energy after loading Pt NPs, which may be due to the larger ionic radius of Pt (1.28 Å) metal than Mn (1.17 Å). No significant Pt or PtOx characteristic peaks were observed in the XRD patterns of the synthesized Pt/(β- and γ-)MnO2 catalysts. This may be due to the very low load of platinum (1 %) and small particles, resulting in peak width. In addition, the particle sizes of different MnO2 catalysts are calculated by Debye-Scherrer formula (D= kλ/(βcostθ)). The grain sizes of Pt/β-MnO2, Pt/γ-MnO2, β-MnO2, and γ-MnO2 are 3.76, 6.18, 5.48, and 4.15 nm, respectively. Pt/β-MnO2 catalyst has the smallest grain size, which is conducive to the formation of oxygen vacancy. It has been reported that the presence of oxygen vacancies can affect CO catalytic activity [30]. Raman technology is used to investigate the changes of oxygen species structure on the surface of different MnO2 catalysts (Fig. 3(b)). The presence of several peaks at 240–350 cm–1 and 590–650 cm–1 mainly correspond to bridge-type oxygen (M1-O-M2) and terminal-type oxygen (M=O). The position of M=O in the Raman spectrum moves from 636 cm−1 to 639 cm−1 after the addition of Pt into different MnO2 catalysts. The reason for the deviation is that the Pt atom support increases the interaction between the ions on the catalyst surface. This affects the symmetric vibration of the O atom around the Mn-O bond of the Mn ion and results in lattice distortion (oxygen vacancy). Meanwhiles, the ratio M=O/(M=O+M1-O-M2) can be used to evaluate the content of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [18]. The ratio of M=O/(M=O+M1-O-M2) is Pt/β-MnO2 (0.87) > γ-MnO2 (0.75) > β-MnO2 (0.54) > Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.42). Pt/β-MnO2 has the highest M=O/(M=O+M1-O-M2) ratio, which indicates that its surface has the most oxygen vacancy content and contributes to low-temperature CO oxidation. EPR can visually evaluate the content of oxygen vacancies on different MnO2 catalysts surface as shown in Fig. 3(c). The area of the half-peak height of different catalysts in EPR can be used to evaluate the concentration of oxygen vacancy on the catalyst surface. The oxygen vacancy content of different MnO2 catalysts is Pt/β-MnO2 (2.37) > γ-MnO2 (2.02) > β-MnO2 (1.64) > Pt/γ-MnO2 (1.45). The surface oxygen vacancy content of Pt/β-MnO2 is the highest, which further validates the Raman results. Among them, Pt/β-MnO2 and Pt/γ-MnO2 catalysts have different EPR spectra because Pt/β-MnO2 (Pt/γ-MnO2) and Mn ions in MnO2 contain unpaired electrons. These unpaired electrons split energy levels under the action of an applied magnetic field and undergo excited state transitions under the irradiation of electromagnetic waves of a specific frequency. This process results in the chemical environment and spin states of PtOx and unpaired electrons with different MnO2 structures. 3.4 Surface chemical element analysis The chemical state and composition of elements were analyzed by XPS technique. Fig. 4 shows the XPS spectra of all elements (including Mn, O, and Pt) in different MnO2 catalysts. In addition, the ratios of different valence elements in Table 1 are obtained by semi-quantitative analysis. XPS spectra of Mn2p for different MnO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. S2(a). The characteristic peaks at 641.2 eV, 641.8 eV, 642.5 eV, 643.2 eV, 644.3 eV, and 645.4 eV are attributed to Mn(IV). The characteristic peak at 640.6 eV is attributed to Mn(III) on the catalysts surface [31,32]. Mn4+ and Mn3+ exist on the surface of different MnO2 catalysts, but their contents are not the same. The Mn(III)/Mn(IV) ratio on the surface of MnO2 catalyst is Pt/β-MnO2 (0.25) > γ-MnO2 (0.18) > β-MnO2 (0.11) > Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.09). Pt/β-MnO2 has the highest Mn(III)/Mn(IV) ratio, while Pt/γ-MnO2 has the lowest Mn(III)/Mn(IV) ratio. It is reported that the increase in the proportion of Mn3+ may be caused by the interaction of Pt NPs with MnO2 carriers and contribute to the formation of oxygen vacancies. Pt/β-MnO2 has more abundant oxygen vacancies. In the Pt4f spectrum (Fig. S2(b)), the binding energies of 72.7 (Pt 4 f7/2) and 76.1 eV (Pt 4 f5/2) belong to surface Pt2+, while the binding energies of 74.6 (Pt 4 f7/2) and 78.0 eV (Pt 4 f5/2) belong to surface Pt4+ [33]. It is worth noting that the formation of Pt2+ ions is the result of electron transfer at the surface interface of MnO2 catalyst and Pt NPs. The content of Pt2+ on Pt/β-MnO2 (0.42) and Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.33) surfaces is different. Relevant studies have shown that the presence of Pt2+ is conducive to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and accelerates the oxygen activation process. The Pt2+ content on Pt/β-MnO2 (0.68) and Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.51) surfaces increased significantly after the reaction, indicating that PtOx compounds were reduced and some oxygen vacancies are generated. This phenomenon can have a certain effect on CO oxidation. XPS spectra of O1s for different MnO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. S2(c). The presence of two peaks at 529.5 eV and 531.2 eV is indicative of the surface lattice oxygen (Olatt) and surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively [31]. By comparing the Oads/Olatt ratio of MnO2 with the corresponding Pt/MnO2 catalysts (see Table 1), it is found that the Oads/Olatt ratio varies greatly after Pt loading MnO2 with different structures. The Oads/Olatt ratio of different MnO2 catalysts are Pt/β-MnO2 (0.53) > γ-MnO2 (0.42) > β-MnO2 (0.37) > Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.31). This may be due to the SMSI effect between Pt and MnO2, which leads to the formation of an asymmetric structure of Pt-O-Mn, thus enhancing the presence of adsorbed oxygen on the Pt/β-MnO2 catalyst surface. It has been reported that the more surface oxygen can promote the catalyst to have higher reactive oxygen species capacity. 3.5 Surface active oxygen species and redox analysis The interaction between the metal and support in the catalyst plays a pivotal role in the reaction process. SMSI not only contributes to the production of reactive oxygen species, but also regulates the local electronic properties of the catalyst surface. It is theorized that loading Pt NPs on MnO2 support can enhance the activity of Pt/MnO2 catalyst and promote the migration and transformation of reactive oxygen species. The activity of the catalyst for CO oxidation is improved. To gain a deeper understanding of the impact of the metal-support interaction on reactive oxygen species, O2-TPD tests are conducted on both MnO2 and Pt/MnO2 catalysts. Fig. 4(a) displays the O2-TPD profiles of various MnO2 catalysts. As the temperature rises, the primary desorption peaks of the MnO2 and Pt/MnO2 catalysts are situated in temperature ranges below 250 °C and above 600 °C, respectively. These correspond to surface-adsorbed oxygen species and bulk lattice oxygen species, respectively [34]. Notably, the O2 desorption behavior of all Pt/MnO2 catalysts differs significantly from that of pure MnO2 catalysts, particularly with respect to the desorption of surface-adsorbed oxygen. In comparison to the corresponding β-MnO2 catalysts, the desorption peak intensity of the Pt/β-MnO2 catalyst is noticeably enhanced and shifts to a lower temperature, falling below 25 °C. This phenomenon suggests that Pt nanoparticles can effectively increase the migration and conversion ability of reactive oxygen species on the Pt/MnO2 catalyst surface. In addition, the oxygen desorption capacity of Pt/MnO2 catalysts are also different due to the different crystal structure of the carrier. TG-MS is used to test the catalyst structure and desorption oxygen (Fig. 4(b)). Among them, the weight loss of γ-MnO2 and Pt/β-MnO2 in the first stage are 3.32 % and 1.01 %, respectively. Meanwhiles, O2MS signal also showed obvious changes in the amount of O2 released in the first stage (Fig. 4(c)). This observation is in line with the O2-TPD findings. The weight loss rate of different MnO2 in the second stage is also different, respectively, Pt/β-MnO2 (12.02 %) > β-MnO2 (9.63 %) > γ-MnO2 (5.46 %) > Pt/γ-MnO2 (2.60 %). These results further confirm that the addition of Pt can affect the activation and deionization processes of surface and lattice oxygen of MnO2 catalysts. H2-TPR profiles of different MnO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 4(d). The hydrogen consumption peaks of two regions can be divided in the test temperature range. In the first stage, the hydrogen consumption peak of Pt/β-MnO2 appeared at 86 °C, and its initial and peak temperatures are significantly lower than those of the other three MnO2 catalysts. However, Pt/γ-MnO2 catalyst does not show hydrogen consumption peak at this stage. This phenomenon implies that different lattice MnO2 catalysts have different SMSI effects on the addition of Pt and the surface PtOx reduction capacity (O migration capacity) is also different [18,35]. In the second stage, hydrogen consumption peaks appeared in different MnO2 catalysts, which was mainly due to the reduction of adjacent manganese species (Mn-O-Mn, MnO, PtO, and Pt-O-Mn) of Pt. The reduction temperature of Pt/γ-MnO2 is much lower, indicating that it can more easily activate surface oxygen near the Pt. Therefore, it showed high catalytic activity for the oxidation of CO, which was consistent with the activity evaluation results. 3.6 N2 adsorption/desorption analysis Fig. 5 illustrates the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm curves of different MnO2 catalysts. Specific surface area and pore size distribution data are provided in Table 2. According to the IUPAC classification, Pt/β-MnO2 and β-MnO2 catalysts do not have any lag rings. They are more similar to type II isotherms which are typical of no holes or large holes adsorbents (such as rods or needles). Similarly, for Pt/γ-MnO2 and γ-MnO2 catalysts there is no limited absorption due to the high P/P0 range. These are closer to the H3 or H4 isotherms, which are typical plate particles and slit pores, which are in good agreement with the morphology of γ-MnO2 catalysts. The specific surface area of different MnO2 catalysts follows the order: 47.78 m2 g−1 (Pt/β-MnO2) > 33.03 m2 g−1 (γ-MnO2) > 29.32 m2 g−1 (β-MnO2) > 25.40 m2 g−1 (Pt/γ-MnO2). It has been reported that a higher specific surface area will increase the number of reaction sites and thus increase the catalytic activity [36]. Based on these findings, the Pt/β-MnO2 catalyst may exhibit superior CO catalytic activity. 3.7 DFT calculation To further analyze the differences in the activities of different catalysts, the E ads of CO adsorption energy at Mn and O sites are calculated by DFT technology. CO adsorption energy of different MnO2 catalysts at Mn sites is shown in Fig. 6. The adsorption energies of different MnO2 catalysts at the Mn site are −2.64 (Pt/β-MnO2 (110)) < -0.7 (γ-MnO2 (120)) < -0.27 (β-MnO2 (110)) < -0.16 (Pt/γ-MnO2 (110)), respectively [37]. The lowest adsorption energy of CO is found on Pt/β-MnO2, indicating that Pt/β-MnO2 has a strong adsorption capacity for CO. This is consistent with the results of catalytic activity. Projected Density of State (PDOS) of Pt/β-MnO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 7. The results show that the 2π* antibonding orbitals of O2 molecules adsorbed on Pt/β-MnO2 surface are partially filled with electrons transferred by 3d orbitals of platinum atoms. In the free O2 molecule, the 2π* antibonding orbital is empty. This remarkable orbital hybridization shows that Pt/β-MnO2 can effectively activate O2 molecules and improve their catalytic activity. 3.8 Operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS analysis 3.8.1 The oxidation of CO by surface oxygen species To delve deeper into the migration and transformation process of oxygen and intermediates on the catalyst surface, operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS is employed. Fig. 8 displays the DRIFTS spectra of the different MnO2 catalysts under CO/Ar atmosphere. The distinct peaks of various oxygen species are observed at 780, 980, 1100, 1180, and 1300 cm−1, indicating M-O-Mn [31], M(-O-)2Mn [38], M2+-O2 2− [39], M+ -O2 − [40,41], and M=O [42]. Additionally, peaks at 1510 and 1590 cm−1 represent monodentate carbonate (v as (CO3 2−)) [43] and bidentate carbonate (v as (OCO)) [44]. Figs. 9 and S3 display the normalized intensities and CO2MS signals of various MnO2 catalysts under CO/Ar atmosphere. As the temperature increases, the catalyst surface exhibits varying oxygen species with different coverage rates. This gives rise to distinct reaction characteristics among the different oxygen species. The normalized intensity of PtO starts to decrease at 50 °C, exhibiting a decreasing trend (Pt/β-MnO2 (-0.02) < Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.00)) (Fig. 9(a)). Simultaneously, the gas-phase CO2 begins to increase (Fig. S3). The order of CO2 MS signal at 50 °C is Pt/β-MnO2 (0.2E-11) > γ-MnO2 (0.1E-11) > β-MnO2 (0) = Pt/γ-MnO2 (0). This phenomenon indicates that the coverage of PtO is greater following Pt loading, and it reacts first. PtO can react with CO to form M=Ov and gas-phase CO2 (Eq. (2)). At temperatures above 100 °C, the normalized intensity of MnO also starts to decline (Fig. 9(b)). Notably, the normalized intensity of v as (CO3 2−) begins to increase within this temperature range (Fig. S4(a)). Upon comparing the reaction rates of the pertinent oxygen species and intermediates, it becomes evident that MnO reacts with CO to yield Mn-Ov and gas-phase CO2 (where Ov stands for oxygen vacancy) (Eq. (3)). A fraction of the resultant gas-phase CO2 is adsorbed on MnO to form v as (CO3 2−) (Eq. (4)). This alignment corresponds with the subsequent increase in the CO2MS signal above 100 °C. Upon reaching temperatures above 150 °C, the normalized intensity of M(-O-)2Mn or M-O-Mn begins to decline, while v as (OCO) exhibits an increase. Furthermore, a secondary increase in the CO2MS signal is observed above 150 °C, further affirming that M(-O-)2Mn or M-O-Mn oxygen species have the slowest reaction rate, necessitating higher temperatures for their occurrence. The specific reactions are as follows: M(-O-)2Mn or M-O-Mn react with CO to produce M-Ov-O-Mn or M-Ov-Mn (Eqs. (5)and (6)). O2 is adsorbed on Ov in the form of M+ -O2 −. To maintain charge conservation, M+ -O2 − is transformed into M2+-O2 2− (Eq. (7)&(8)). A small amount of CO adsorbs on M2+-O2 2− to form v as (OCO) (Eq. (9)) [45]. (2) Pt = O + CO → Pt = O v + C O 2 (3) Mn = O + CO → Mn = O v + C O 2 (4) M = O + C O 2 → M − O − C O 2 (5) M ( − O − ) 2 Mn + CO → M − O v − O − Mn + C O 2 (6) M − O − Mn + CO → M − O v − Mn + C O 2 ( O 2 − ) − M ( − O − ) 2 Mn + CO → ( O 2 2 − ) = M − O v − O − Mn + CO 2 (7) (8) ( O 2 − ) − M − O − Mn + CO → ( O 2 2 − ) = M − O v − Mn + CO 2 (9) M2+=O2 2–+CO → M-O2-CO 3.8.2 Oxidation of CO+O2 by surface oxygen species To investigate whether O2 plays a promoting role in the reaction process, CO+O2/Ar gas is introduced into the in-situ cell for testing. Fig. 10 and Fig. S5 display the DRIFTS spectra and normalized intensities of different MnO2 catalysts. The trend of surface oxygen species are basically consistent with that in the absence of oxygen. The peak intensities of PtO, MnO, M-O-Mn, M(-O-)2Mn, and M+ -O2 − decrease with increasing temperature, while the peak height of M2+-O2 2−, v as (CO3 2−), and v as (OCO) increased successively. The difference is that the reaction temperature of oxygen species on the surface of the catalyst in the presence of O2 is lower than that in the absence of O2, and the reaction rate is faster. For example, the trend in variation of PtO at 50 °C under CO+O2/Ar atmosphere indicates Pt/β-MnO2 (-0.04) < Pt/γ-MnO2 (0.00) (Fig. S5(a)). The reaction rate of PtO is increased by 0.02 compared to CO/Ar atmosphere. CO2MS signals of different MnO2 catalysts under the CO+O2/Ar atmosphere are displayed in Fig. S6. It is also noted that the CO2MS signal in the presence of O2 (4.0E-09) is much higher than the CO2MS signal in the absence of O2 (3.1E-11) at 300 °C. The above results show that the presence of O2 is conducive to promoting the CO oxidation. 3.8.3 Regeneration of oxygen species In order to investigate the regeneration ability of the catalyst, the catalyst is placed in CO+O2/Ar atmosphere at high temperature for reaction. Subsequently, the CO/Ar gas is cut off at room temperature and passed into the O2/Ar gas for oxidation test (Table S1). The DRIFTS spectra and normalized intensities at different temperatures under O2/Ar atmosphere are shown in Fig. 11 and Fig. S7. In the CO+O2/Ar atmosphere, the oxygen species of the catalyst still exist in the form of negative peaks, and the oxygen species (PtO, MnO, M(-O-)2Mn, and M-O-Mn) on the surface are reacting with CO. When only O2 is present and as the temperature increases, the normalized intensities of PtO, MnO, M(-O-)2Mn, and M-O-Mn on Pt/β-MnO2 begin to rise above 100 °C. The oxygen filling of Pt/β-MnO2 requires the lowest temperature (200 °C) compared to other MnO2 catalysts (Fig. S7). The main step of oxygen species recovery on the surface of Pt/β-MnO2 is that O2 is first adsorbed on the surface of Ov in the form of M2+-O2 2−. As the temperature increases, M2+-O2 2− can be decomposed and formed into MnO, M(-O-)2Mn, and M-O-Mn (Eq. (10) & Eq. (11)) [46]. Notably, it was observed that recovery of reactive oxygen species on the surface of γ-MnO2, β-MnO2, and Pt/γ-MnO2 catalysts necessitates higher temperatures. This phenomenon may be related to the content of Ov on the catalyst surface and the ability of the catalyst to adsorb O2. The above results show that Pt/β-MnO2 has a stronger oxidation capacity, and the SMSI effect is conducive to the migration and transformation of oxygen on the surface of β-MnO2 catalyst. (10) (O2 2-)M-Ov-Mn → M-O-Mn=O (11) (O2 2-)M-Ov-O-Mn → M(-O-)2Mn=O 3.8.4 Gasification of surface carbonates To investigate the desorption properties of different carbonates on the catalyst surface, a series of relevant experiments have been conducted. Fig. 12 displays the DRIFTS spectra and peak heights of v as (CO3 2−) and v as (OCO) on Pt/β-MnO2 at various temperatures. Upon surpassing 100 °C, the peak height of v as (CO3 2−) starts to decline. In contrast, the peak height of v as (OCO) gradually diminishes above 300 °C (Fig. 12(b)) [47], indicating that v as (OCO) necessitates a higher temperature than v as (CO3 2−) for gasification. These findings additionally signify that the type of carbonates on the catalyst surface is a determinant factor influencing the CO oxidation rate. 3.9 CO oxidation mechanism Fig. 13(a) shows the CO oxidation process on the Pt/β-MnO2 surface. β-MnO2 catalyst is mainly composed of Mn-O-Mn structure. Step 1: Pt mainly exists on β-MnO2 surface in the form of PtO. PtO reacts with CO at 50 °C to form PtOv and gas phase CO2. Step 2: MnO and M-O-Mn also react with CO to generate MnOv, M-Ov-Mn, and gas-phase CO2 at 100 °C. Step 3: a part of gas-phase CO2 adsorbs on MnO to create v as (CO3 2−), which readily decomposes at lower temperatures and releases Ov sites. Step 4: O2 adsorption exists on Ov sites in the form of M+ -O2 −. Step 5: In order to retain the charge, M+ -O2 − is converted into M2+-O2 2−. M2+-O2 2− dissociates and activates at specific temperatures into PtO, MnO, and M-O-Mn, following the Epling-Xu mechanism. Fig. 13(b) shows the CO oxidation process on the Pt/γ-MnO2 surface. β-MnO2 catalyst is mainly composed of MnO and M(-O-)2Mn structure. Step 1: Pt mainly exists in the form of PtO2 on the surface of γ-MnO2. PtO2 reacts with CO leads to the formation of PtOv and gas-phase CO2 at 100°C. Step 2: MnO, M(-O-)2Mn, and M-O-Mn also react with CO to generate MnOv, M-Ov-O-Mn, M-Ov-Mn, and gas-phase CO2 at 150°C. Step 3: O2 is adsorbed on the catalyst's surface as M+ -O2 −. Once Ov sites are created, M+ -O2 − is transformed into M2+-O2 2−. Step 4: Gas-phase CO adsorbs on M2+-O2 2− to create v as (OCO). v as (OCO) decomposes at higher temperatures and releases Ov sites. Step 5: M2+-O2 2− is dissociated and activated into PtO, MnO, M(-O-)2Mn, and M-O-Mn at a specific temperature, following Epling-Xu mechanism. 4 Conclusion In this paper, Pt/MnO2 catalysts with different crystal structures (β- and γ-) of MnO2 are used as the research object and operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS is used to investigate the changes of oxygen species on the catalyst surface. Pt mainly exists in elemental form on the surface of β-MnO2 and PtO2 form on the surface of γ-MnO2. Pt support different crystals of MnO2 catalysts can produce positive and negative SMSI effects. SMSI effect greatly improves catalyst’s redox ability and desorption ability of surface oxygen adsorption. Pt/β-MnO2 has the best CO oxidation activity (200 ℃) and redox activity. DFT results show that Pt/β-MnO2 has strong adsorption capacity for CO. Operando DRIFTS results indicate that the presence of PtO on the Pt/β-MnO2 surface is the initial site for CO reaction at 50° C. As the temperature rises, MnO and Pt-O-Mn also participate in CO reaction, leading to the formation of MnOv, Pt-Ov-Mn and gas-phase CO2. It is worth noting that the production of Pt-Ov-Mn plays a beneficial role in accelerating O2 decomposition. Among them, the presence of carbonate has a significant effect on the activation of Pt-Ov-Mn. Carbonate plays a decisive role in the activation of O2. Specifically, monodentate carbonates break down more easily at lower temperatures. These findings offer compelling support for comprehending the impact of the SMSI effect on the inherent configuration of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Strong metal support interaction (SMSI) between precious metals and metal oxide support is an effective strategy to improve catalyst activity. However, the interfacial effects of SMSI on the catalyst surface are not clear. In this paper, Pt/MnO2 catalysts with different MnO2 crystal structures (β- and γ-) are used as research objects, and operando TPR-DRIFTS-MS is used as characterization technique. Pt/β-MnO2 exhibited the highest CO oxidation activity (200 °C) and CO2 selectivity (100 °C) due to its excellent redox properties. Among them, β-MnO2 surface Pt mainly exists in the form of elemental Pt, while γ-MnO2 surface Pt mainly exists in the form of PtO2. Different forms of Pt have positive and negative effects on different MnO2 crystals. DFT results show that Pt/β-MnO2 has strong adsorption capacity for CO. Operando DRIFTS results indicate that Pt/β-MnO2 surface PtO first reacts with CO to produce PtOv (Ov represent oxygen vacancy) at low temperature. As the temperature rises, MnO and Pt-O-Mn also participate in CO reaction, forming MnOv, Pt-Ov-Mn and gas-phase CO2. It is worth noting that the formation of Pt-Ov-Mn plays an important role in the activation of O2. The surface carbonate of the catalyst inhibited the activation of Pt-Ov-Mn. More PtO sites are conducive to the production of monodentate carbonate and the easier decomposition at low temperature, which is the decisive step of CO oxidation. These findings provide strong support for understanding the effect of SMSI effect on the intrinsic configuration of catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Revealing the positive and negative effects of strong metal support interactions on CO oxidation for Pt-supported different crystals (β- and γ-) MnO2 catalysts: Pt oxides and carbonate species
